Problem:
Consider the function \( z(t) = e^{i\omega t}x(t) \) acting on a complex function \( x(t) \), where \( \omega \) is a constant frequency. We examine the consequences of applying an Integral transform \( \mathcal{L} \) defined by \( \mathcal{L}\{x(t)\} = \int_0^\infty e^{-st}x(t) \, dt \) over time t.

If at a certain time \( t_1 \), an additional unitary transformation \( u(t) = e^{-i\eta t}x(t) \) (where \( \eta \) is a new constant frequency) is applied as an intervention, will the transformed output \( \mathcal{L}\{z(t)\} \) for t > \( t_1 \) depend only on the original transformation \( z(t) \) irrespective of \( u(t) \)?
Explanation: The intervention with \( u(t) \) alters the state again, adding another frequency component \( -i\eta \). Even if \( \mathcal{L}\{z(t)\} \) was established prior to \( t_1 \), the subsequent state will reflect the compounding effect of the two transformations, affecting the output in a manner dependent on both \( \eta \) and \( \omega \).
